Situation1: They openly turn to each other for help in a difficult personal moment.
Expectation2: Design and develop technical solutions to meet project requirements
Situation2: The project is still in exploratory discussions, and alternative approaches can be proposed later
Story:
My phone buzzed just as I was sketching out a new circuit design for the project. It was my younger brother, his name lighting up the screen. I hesitated, knowing he rarely called unless something was wrong. As his sister, I’d always been the one he leaned on, the one who listened when things got tough. I could hear the strain in his voice as he asked if I had a moment—he needed to talk, really talk, about something that was weighing on him.

But my mind was tangled in the technical challenge in front of me. The team was counting on me to propose a new approach for the project, and even though we were still in the early stages, I felt the pressure to deliver something innovative. I knew I could suggest alternatives later, but I also knew how quickly ideas could get dismissed if I wasn’t present and engaged.

I stared at my notes, then at my phone, feeling the pull from both sides. My brother needed me now, but so did my team. The expectations pressed in, and I felt myself caught in the middle, torn between being the sister he could rely on and the engineer my colleagues depended on.
